Award.AwardTitle: National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education (MatEd)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: With rapid changes and new developments in nanotechnology, corrosion, composites, biomaterials and green technologies, as well as the traditional areas of metals, ceramics and plastics, industry needs qualified technicians educated in materials and advanced manufacturing. The Resource Center for Materials Technology Education (MatEd) builds on its previous efforts to broaden access to resources for faculty educating materials and manufacturing technicians and other materials professionals through an innovative, easily accessible website with linkages to curriculum materials, workshops, conferences journals and professional organizations. The collection of peer-reviewed, high quality instructional modules aligned with industry-based core competencies for technicians in both traditional and new advanced materials technologies is increased and disseminated broadly to help faculty enhance current courses and develop new ones. Partnerships created with other ATE centers in welding, rapid prototyping, and aerospace and with professional societies ensure a comprehensive collection of use to technician education. Strategies to ensure the sustainability of the web site are developed. The evaluation measures the usefulness of the materials and the core competencies to faculty and other users.

Project Outcomes Report, DUE #0903112

MatEd, 2009-2015

 

MatEd responds to the national need for state-of-the-art curriculum and instructional resources in materials technology to strengthen the engineering and advanced manufacturing workforce in the US. MatEd develops and offers an array of educational resources pertinent to materials, and materials technology teaching and learning, for community and technical college programs, as well as for K-12. MatEd provides the instructional content, tools, and resources to understand materials technology, advanced manufacturing, and engineering design and production processes. It is essential for STEM students and technicians to understand the quantity and complexity of materials used in advanced manufacturing industries and related sectors. With program-appropriate curricula, flexible delivery formats (courses, workshops, modules, hands-on labs), and a validated set of core competencies in materials technology, MatEd helps to enable and enhance technician education across the nation. This in turn helps ensure the US remains globally competitive in advanced materials and manufacturing technologies.

 

MatEd began its foundational work in materials technology by: a) identifying and creating much-needed core competencies for education; b) collecting and adapting curriculum modules, labs, and classroom activities, for use by a wider audience; c) providing innovative and flexible professional development for faculty and teachers; and d) establishing an informative and useful website, materialseducation.org, to centrally house all of these resources. MatEd’s national, regional, and local partners, as well as other institutions throughout the country, are using MatEd’s educational resources in such areas as metals, composites, and plastics technology. To meet the challenge of new and emerging needs, MatEd will continue its work to address areas such as electronic, nano- and bio-materials, as well as corrosion and green materials processing.

 

The major goals of MatEd have been to: 1) Broaden access to resources for materials technology education through an up-to-date, innovative and easily accessible website; 2)

Improve and broaden the project curriculum collection to encompass high-quality modules both in traditional and new advanced materials technologies focused at the technician level; 3)

Broaden dissemination strategies to include an enhanced website, increased partnerships, stronger regional and national support systems, and expanded professional development opportunities; and 4) Implement a long-term program plan of sustainability by exploring and developing revenue streams and leveraged resources.

 

MatEd has fulfilled its goals via the following outcomes and achievements:

  1. Connecting a national audience of educators to best practices in materials technology and materials instruction, especially for technician education. MatEd is helping to transform materials science education in the US.
  2. Producing a replicable competency development model that can be used to organize courses and programs. The Center has also created a library of materials-related modules to support materials technology teaching and learning.
  3. Refining its dissemination and outreach strategies. Continuous improvement by the MatEd team has focused on targeting specific audiences with appropriate content, tools, and educational resources. This effort has enabled greater impact of MatEd’s work by reaching specific educational audiences that can benefit most.
